title: Inside a Sequencing Lab on the Front Lines of America’s Search for Omicron
content: More states are finding cases of the new variant. Tracking its spread, experts say, is key to understanding what threat it poses.

title: Omicron Variant Spreading Twice as Quickly as Delta in South Africa
content: A new mathematical analysis strengthens concerns about the effects of the new variant on the pandemic’s course.

title: Cognitive Rehab: One Patient’s Painstaking Path Through Long Covid Therapy
content: Samantha Lewis is relearning some basic aspects of her daily life after struggling with brain fog and other lingering symptoms for more than a year since being infected by the virus.

more_info.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alex Wroblewski

title: Upstate New York Hospitals Are Overwhelmed as Covid Cases Surge
content: Health care officials say a “perfect storm” of new Covid cases, staff shortages and filled nursing homes has created a crisis.

title: Parents of Michigan Shooting Suspect Arrested in Detroit, Police Say
content: The couple were charged after officials said their son carried out the shootings using a handgun his parents had bought for him.

org_facet: Oxford High School (Oxford Charter Township, Mich)

title: Read the Prosecutor’s Account of Events Before the Michigan School Shooting
content: In a news conference, the prosecutor in Oakland County, Mich., detailed what led the county to criminally charge the parents of the 15-year-old student accused of killing four classmates.

title: Israeli Company’s Spyware Is Used to Target U.S. Embassy Employees in Africa
content: The hack is the first known case of the spyware, known as Pegasus, being used against American officials.

more_info.byline: By Katie Benner, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

title: November Jobs Report Shows Weak Hiring but a Surge in the Labor Force
content: Employers reported adding 210,000 jobs, the year’s weakest showing, but there were also bright spots. The mixed picture complicated policy prospects.

more_info.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith

title: Why the November Jobs Report Is Better Than It Looks
content: The number of jobs added was below expectations, but otherwise the report shows an economy on the right track.

title: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen
content: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.

more_info.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

title: In Afghanistan, ‘Who Has the Guns Gets the Land’
content: A decades-long fight over land has been reinvigorated as Taliban leaders look to reward their fighters with property, even if that means evicting others.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek

title: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?
content: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.

title: The Great ‘West Side Story’ Debate
content: With the Steven Spielberg film coming soon, three critics, a playwright and a theater historian weigh in on whether the musical deserves a new hearing — and how.

title: Samba, Cachaça and Pickled Eggs: ‘Dirty Feet’ Bars Are ‘Essence of Rio’
content: A cross between a dive bar and a greasy spoon, Rio de Janeiro’s beloved (and proudly filthy) hole-in-the wall joints are some of the most democratic spaces in a deeply unequal city.

more_info.byline: By Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri

title: Best TV Shows of 2021
content: From Bo Burnham to “We Are Lady Parts,” the best in television this year offered ingenuity, humor, defiance and hope.

more_info.byline: By James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Margaret Lyons

title: English Teenager Finds Bronze Age Ax Using a Metal Detector
content: On her third day out with a metal detector, Milly Hardwick, 13, found a hoard of items from more than 3,000 years ago. “We were just laughing our heads off,” she said.

title: Losing the Lawyer Lottery Shouldn’t End in Execution
content: Two Arizona men who were appointed ineffective lawyers landed on death row. If Arizona has its way, the Supreme Court will close an already narrow avenue for relief.

title: The Supreme Court Gaslights Its Way to the End of Roe
content: The only question is, how will they explain it?

title: I Was the Governor of Montana. My Fellow Democrats, You Need to Get Out of the City More.
content: It’s time to ditch the grand ideological narratives and talk to voters about their real needs.

title: Believe It or Not, I Like Some Things in Our Progressive Era
content: It’s good to acknowledge our past and our diversity.

title: Behind Low Vaccination Rates Lurks a More Profound Social Weakness
content: Vaccine hesitancy reflects a transformation of people’s core beliefs about what we owe each other.

title: The Great Resignation Won’t Last Forever
content: Americans are waiting for the right opportunity to jump back into the work force.

title: The Trump Conspiracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
content: Large and influential parts of the Republican Party are increasingly untethered from any commitment to electoral democracy.

title: The Only Mother on the Court
content: Justice Amy Coney Barrett seemed to lean into identity politics at Wednesday’s arguments over a major abortion case.

title: Why the Fed Chair Won’t Call Inflation ‘Transitory’ Anymore
content: Jerome Powell has lost patience with the pace of the rebound in labor force participation.

title: In Africa, Dealing With Vaccine Challenges and the Omicron Variant
content: Vaccine shortages and skepticism, and rewarding countries for discovering variants. Also: Happiness and politics; unwanted children; beware of psychedelics.

title: Predicting the Future Is Possible. These ‘Superforecasters’ Know How.
content: The psychologist Philip Tetlock on the art and science of prediction.

title: Wonking Out: Money Isn’t Everything
content: No, not even in macroeconomics.

title: I Was Adopted. I Know the Trauma It Can Inflict.
content: What Amy Coney Barrett doesn’t realize is that adoption is often infinitely more difficult, expensive, dangerous and potentially traumatic than terminating a pregnancy in its early stages.

title: Parenting’s Hard. Join Us and the Comedian Michelle Buteau to Vent.
content: As we approach another pandemic holiday season, let’s laugh about the “joys” of parenting, at a Dec. 8 virtual event hosted by Jessica Grose of The Times’s Opinion newsletter on parenting.

title: The Metaverse Is Coming, and the World Is Not Ready for It
content: The geopolitical consequences may be radical.

title: A Way to Break the Cycle of Poverty
content: Intervening in children’s lives early can help break the cycle of intergenerational poverty.

title: Omicron Is Here. Should You Cancel Your Trip?
content: Most people have become used to making health-risk assessments during the pandemic, but that doesn’t make the decision about whether to travel or cancel easier — especially with a new variant circulating.

title: Marcus Lamb, Christian Broadcaster and Vaccine Skeptic, Dies of Covid at 64
content: Mr. Lamb, who co-founded the Daystar Television Network, repeatedly suggested on air that people pray instead of getting vaccinated.

title: The Coronavirus in a Tiny Drop
content: A new simulation shows how the virus survives inside tiny airborne particles of water — and gives clues about how the Delta variant became dominant.

more_info.byline: By Carl Zimmer and Jonathan Corum

title: Best Albums of 2021
content: Less isolation didn’t mean a return to normalcy. Albums with big feelings and room for catharsis made the most powerful connections.

more_info.byline: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz

title: Prior Infection Is Little Defense Against Virus Variant, Scientists Say
content: Evidence from South Africa, where the Omicron variant already dominates, shows a high rate of reinfection of people who have already had the coronavirus.

more_info.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Richard Pérez-Peña

title: Talking About the Best Books of 2021
content: On a special episode of the podcast, taped live, editors from The New York Times Book Review discuss this year’s outstanding fiction and nonfiction.

title: Federal Scrutiny of Cuomo Widens to His Office’s Treatment of Women
content: The Justice Department opened an inquiry into reports of sexual harassment and retaliation in the former governor’s administration.

title: U.S. Intelligence Sees Russian Plan for Possible Ukraine Invasion
content: An invasion force could include 175,000 troops, but U.S. officials stress that President Vladimir V. Putin’s intentions remain unclear.

title: Money Found by Plumber at Joel Osteen’s Church Is Tied to 2014 Burglary, Police Say
content: The discovery was revealed when the plumber called into a Houston radio show on Thursday.

title: Congo Ousts Mining Leader in a Cloud of Corruption Claims
content: The country’s president removed Albert Yuma Mulimbi as chairman of the state mining firm. Cobalt in Congo is a crucial resource in the global clean energy revolution.

title: U.S. Opens Civil Rights Investigation Into Police in New York Suburb
content: The inquiry will focus on whether the Mount Vernon department engaged in a “pattern or practice of unlawful policing,” officials said.

title: Suspect in Mass Killing at Colorado Grocery Store Is Mentally Incompetent, Judge Says
content: The man accused of murdering 10 people in Boulder, Colo., in March will be sent to a state hospital “to restore his competency as soon as possible so that we may proceed forward with the case,” prosecutors said.

title: Biden Releases a Doctor’s Note: It’s Just a Cold
content: President Biden’s voice sounded noticeably hoarse during the remarks about a Labor Department jobs report, and he coughed at times. He blamed it on his grandson.

title: A Top SoftBank Executive Wants $2 Billion in Pay. His Boss Disagrees.
content: The SoftBank founder, Masayoshi Son, is locked in a dispute over compensation that his key deputy, Marcelo Claure, insists he should be paid.

title: Susan Rosenblatt, Who Took On Big Tobacco, Dies at 70
content: She was the quieter half of a law partnership with her husband that pursued a suit against cigarette companies on behalf of Florida smokers.

title: Five-Minute Coronavirus Stress Resets
content: How to get unstuck from your anxiety.

title: With Omicron Comes Uncertainty. Here’s How to Handle It.
content: Experts share techniques to ease the mental toll of an evolving pandemic.

title: Day 10: Give Yourself a Break!
In Stressful Times, Make Stress Work for You
content: Research shows we can actually use stress to improve our health and well-being. Here’s how.

title: Take a Minute for Mindfulness
content: Meditation doesn’t have to take a lot of time, but it can help make dealing with anxieties much easier. Here are some tips.

title: The Confounding Lightness of Helen Pashgian
content: Long underrecognized for her innovations, a trailblazer of the Light and Space Movement is suddenly juggling three tribute shows to her six-decade career.

title: What Makes a Wine Great? It’s Not Just Old and Complex.
content: It ought to have a sense of place, and it needs to refresh. Beyond that, great wines are those that best fit the particular occasion.

title: ‘The Power of the Dog’: About That Ending
content: The movie’s subtle conclusion takes a moment to comprehend. But the director, Jane Campion, has a history of working in the realm of suggestion.

title: ‘The Anomaly,’ Part Airplane Thriller and Part Exploration of Reality, Fate and Free Will
content: Hervé Le Tellier’s novel, a runaway best seller and prize winner in France, is about the strange and mysterious fate of the passengers on a flight from Paris to New York.

title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
content: Including bomb threats, bank robberies and more, the month’s action films pack a wallop.
